fields.summary: Distcp of file > 5GB to swift fails with HTTP 413 error

status.name: Open

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: Avoid creating "._COPYING_" temporary file when copying file to Swift file system

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.
status.name: Patch Available

fields.description: In the swift filesystem for openstack, a rename operation on a partitioned file uses the swift COPY operation, which attempts to consolidate all of the partitions into a single object.  This causes the rename to fail when the total size of all the partitions exceeds the maximum object size for swift.  Since partitioned files are primarily created to allow a file to exceed the maximum object size, this bug makes writing to swift extremely unreliable.
fields.summary: swiftfs rename on partitioned file attempts to consolidate partitions

comments.body: This patch preserves partitions during a rename operation.

David: how does it detect that a file is partitioned? that length > 0 and that there are children?

Steve: I'm relying on the logic that was already there - if its a file (or rather, not a directory) and the childCount > 0.  

There would be fewer differences in this patch but it seems I've run afoul of some checkstyle rules that weren't there the last time this code was committed (too many lines in method, lines too long, etc).

[~highlycaffeinated] You don't need to change Status from open to Patch Available for every new uploaded patch. As long as the status is Patch available, a new uploaded file (patch) will trigger a new jenkins build.
Thanks Eddy. It doesn't seem to have triggered a new build for my latest patch.  Should I upload it again or just be more patient?

Cleaned up the java and checkstyle warnings.
what's the legal status of something from sahara? Who is the original contributor?

The sahara version of the swiftfs code lives in the [sahara-extra|http://github.com/openstack/sahara-extra] repository, which contains [this|https://github.com/openstack/sahara-extra/blob/master/LICENSE] Apache 2.0 license. Since it was contributed to OpenStack, original contributor rights were surrendered to the OpenStack Foundation, per their [Contributor License Agreement|https://review.openstack.org/static/cla.html].
Hi [~highlycaffeinated], add a auth-keys.xml file under the resource directory of the openstack unit test, it will automatically trigger the openstack unit test and provide you more hints.
I deployed this change in my cluster and was able to successfully put and get files >5GB from a swift container.

This message was automatically generated.

What object store you are talking about. It is also a server side configuration. If your server's config for the maximum size of a object is 10GB, you will not meet this problem. Try to get this info first. Or try to copy a 1TB file to object store, see what happend. :). I just suspect that no server will support this large single object . Please feel free to provide feedback. Thanks!

I used a Bluemix Object Store, where you don't have access to the swift.conf file to change the default maximum object size limit. I think this is good because it separate the dependency between needing to change something in swift for Hadoop to work. This just uses the [Large Object Direct API|http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/overview_large_objects.html#additional-notes] of Swift, which in theory will allow to store 1TB files in several segments without merging them, but still providing a single file to download and combine all the pieces together.

The only issues if that is you hdfs dfs -ls swift://container.store/ you will see the file displaying with size 0, which is also expected from the documentation linked above.
I linked the wrong section, [Large Object Direct API|http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/overview_large_objects.html#direct-api]

I think the reason why the patch get a -1 is because it fails a unit test.
I agree it works in some cases.

Chen He@Oracle from Samsung Mega
Looks like it is failing checkstyle and findbugs checks, not unit tests.

I should add - in the past it was failing unit tests locally for stevel but I was never able to reproduce this behavior, so I wasn't able to update the patch to address it. As far as I can tell, it's not failing unit tests currently, just the findbugs and checkstyle checks.
It automatically skips "unit tests" if the auth-keys.xml is not configured.
Understood. I have auth-keys.xml configured when I run locally and my unit tests run and pass.
